      • isOSExecutable

        public static boolean isOSExecutable(java.io.File file)
        Checks that the file is an executable file on the current OS.

        If the file is a directory or it hasn't got an extension the method will immediately return.

        Example (on Windows) : 

        
     isOSExecutable(new File("file.txt")) => false
     isOSExecutable(new File("program.exe") => true
     isOSExecutable(new File("script.bat") => true
        Note: it checks the file's executability only by it's extension, so it's may be not enough for you List of Executable File Extensions

        This method basically wraps the given File into FormattedFile and calls the isOSExecutable(FormattedFile) method with it.

        Parameters:
        file - the file to check
        Returns:
        true if the file is an executable file; false otherwise
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        isOSExecutable(FormattedFile)

      • isOSExecutable

        public static boolean isOSExecutable(FormattedFile file)
        Checks that the file is an executable file on the current OS.

        If the file is a directory or it hasn't got an extension the method will immediately return.

        Example (on Windows) : 

        
     isOSExecutable(new FormattedFile("file.txt")) => false
     isOSExecutable(new FormattedFile("program.exe") => true
     isOSExecutable(new FormattedFile("script.bat") => true
        Note: it checks the file's executability only by it's extension, so it's may be not enough for you List of Executable File Extensions
        Parameters:
        file - the FormattedFile object that separates the extension from it's name
        Returns:
        true if the file is an executable file; false otherwise
        Since:
        1.0

      • hasValidPath

        public static boolean hasValidPath(java.io.File file)
        Checks that the path of the file is valid or not. If the file object is null it returns immediately false;

        Example (on Windows): 

        
     "C:/Users/User/test.txt" -> {@code true}
     "C?,:.f" -> {@code false}
        Parameters:
        file - the file that we want to check; may be null
        Returns:
        true if the filepath is valid; false otherwise.
        Since:
        1.0

      • hasNotValidPath

        public static boolean hasNotValidPath(java.io.File file)
        Returns the negated value of hasValidPath(File).
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        hasValidPath(File)

      • shortenedFilePath

        public static java.lang.String shortenedFilePath(java.io.File file,
                                                 java.lang.String prefix,
                                                 char separator,
                                                 int maxBack)
        Creates a shortened path from a file.

        It is useful when you don't want to use a very long file-path and you want to short it.


        Let's say you have a file-path /images/background/wallpaper/design/First.png. You want to create a path that only shows the 2 previous directory: .../wallpaper/design/First.png.

        You can specify the:

        • prefix it was '...' in the previous example
        • separator it was '/' in the previous example
        • maxBack - it specifies how many parent directories you want to show. it was 2 in the previous example

        More examples 

        
  shortenedFilePath(new File("programFiles/thePrg/appdata/inf/config.prop"), "<DEFAULT>", '\\', 0) => "<DEFAULT>\config.prop"
  shortenedFilePath(new File("users/user0/documents/Plans.docx"), "[USER_HOME]", '/', 1) => "[USER_HOME]/documents/Plans.docx"
        Parameters:
        file - the file that we want to show a shorter path of
        prefix - the prefix that will be at the start of the string; basically that hides the directories that are not displayed
        separator - the separator character that will separate the paths.
        maxBack - specifies how many directories we want to show before the file's name; if it's less than 0 the method will return an empty string.
        Returns:
        the shortened path
        Since:
        1.0

      • shortenedFilePath

        public static java.lang.String shortenedFilePath(java.io.File file,
                                                 int maxBack,
                                                 char separator)

        Since:

        See Also:

      • shortenedFilePath

        public static java.lang.String shortenedFilePath(java.io.File file,
                                                 int maxBack)
        Calls the shortenedFilePath(File, String, char, int) with the prefix "..." and with the default separator File.separatorChar.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        shortenedFilePath(File, String, char, int)

      • deprecateFile

        public static java.io.File deprecateFile(java.io.File file)
        This method creates a File object that is a modified version of the given file. It's produced this way:
        • Generates a random 5-digit number
        • Adds the '_old' word to the original name of the file
        • Adds the random number to the end of the file name
        The file that this new File object represents is definitely not existing (because the process that is described above will be repeated while we get a file that is not existing). 
             deprecateFile(File("file.txt")) = File("file_old3102.txt")
     deprecateFile(File("path/to/someVideo.mp4")) = File("path/to/someVideo_old4916")

        It is good if let's say you want to save a new file but with that name a file already exist and you don't want to delete the existing file, you just want to rename it. 

        
         //the file that we want to save to
         File toSave = ...;
         if (toSave.exists()) {
             //if a file already with this name exist we rename it
             File deprecateFile = FileGoodies.deprecateFile(toSave);
             toSave.renameTo(deprecateFile);
         }

         //now we can easily save to the file
        Parameters:
        file - the file that we want to rename
        Since:
        1.0
